title: Home
text: Professional Skills for Data Analytics is designed to enhance the professional capacity of students in data analytics. This module provides a comprehensive grounding in essential skills required for data literacy, bolstering existing skills and framing elements of best practice standards. It covers a range of topics including an introduction to R programming, an introduction to traditional statistical analysis and visualization, the creation of GitHub webpages to document and communicate analyses, and the use of Git and Markdown for reproducible practice.

title: Home
text: Professional Skills for Data Analytics is designed to enhance the professional capacity of students in data analytics. This module provides a comprehensive grounding in essential skills required for data literacy, bolstering existing skills and framing elements of best practice standards. title: Home
text:
Harper Adams Data Science

This module is a part of the MSc in Data Science for Global Agriculture, Food, and Environment at Harper Adams University, led by Ed Harris.

Module content

Markdown and Github: Markdown and Github
Statistical reporting: Statistical reporting

title: Statisitical Analysis Report
text:
Importance of statistical analysis reports
Use cases: Business, Consultancy, Scientific Research
Objectives:

Guidelines for report creation
Tailor reports to the audience

title: Statisitical Analysis Report
text:
Understanding the Audience

Who is the report for?

Business managers, clients, scientists

Adjust technical depth based on their knowledge
What key information is expected by the audience?

title: Statisitical Analysis Report
section: Defining the Purpose of the Report
text:
Defining the Purpose of the Report

Clarify the objective: What are you solving or exploring?
Address the key questions or problems
Define the expected outcomes
For a very big analysis create a Statistical Analysis Plan

title: Statisitical Analysis Report
text:
Data Collection and Preparation

Overview of data:

Where did the data come from? How was it collected?

Data cleaning process:

Handling missing data, outliers, normalization

Importance of transparent data preprocessing

title: Statisitical Analysis Report
text:
Choosing the Right Statistical Methods

Criteria for selecting the correct statistical tests:

Parametric vs. Non-parametric

Common tests: T-tests, ANOVA, Regression
Match the method to the data type and objective

title: Statisitical Analysis Report
text:
Data Exploration & Visualization

Visualizing data using histograms, scatter plots, box plots
Summary statistics: Mean, Median, Standard Deviation
Highlight key trends or anomalies in the data

title: Statisitical Analysis Report
text:
Hypothesis Testing (If Applicable)

Define the null and alternative hypotheses
Statistical significance and p-values explained
Interpreting test results for non-technical stakeholders

title: Statisitical Analysis Report
text:
Regression Analysis (If Applicable)

Use of regression to explain relationships between variables
Key metrics: R-squared, Coefficients
Visualizing regression results with graphs

title: Statisitical Analysis Report
text:
Confidence Intervals

Importance of confidence intervals in analysis
How to interpret and explain them
Examples of 95% confidence intervals in real-world scenarios

title: Statisitical Analysis Report
text:
Correlation vs Causation

Correlation explained: Why it doesn’t mean causation
Avoid assumption of causality
Visualizations like correlation matrices help convey relationships

title: Statisitical Analysis Report
text:
Interpreting the Results

Key findings from the statistical analysis
How to explain technical results to non-technical stakeholders
Highlight the actionable insights

title: Statisitical Analysis Report
text:
Limitations and Assumptions

Discuss the limitations of the analysis:

Sampling bias, data quality, test assumptions

Why transparency is important
What can be done to mitigate limitations

title: Statisitical Analysis Report
text:
Visualizing Results

Best practices for choosing visualizations:

Charts, graphs, tables

Ensure clarity and simplicity
Use tools like Excel, R, Python for creating visuals

title: Statisitical Analysis Report
text:
Recommendations Based on the Analysis

Translating statistical results into actionable recommendations
Specific examples for business/scientific decisions:

Increase sales, improve efficiency, refine hypotheses

title: Statisitical Analysis Report
text:
Writing the Report

Typical components of a report:

Executive Summary
Methodology
Results
Discussion and Recommendations

Use plain language, avoid technical jargon

title: Statisitical Analysis Report
text:
Delivering the Report

Tailoring the delivery format:

PDF, PowerPoint, or interactive dashboards

Structuring the narrative for oral presentations
Tips for engaging non-technical audiences

title: Statisitical Analysis Report
text:
Common Pitfalls to Avoid

Avoid data overload or excessive jargon
Be cautious with misinterpretation of results
Always contextualize insights for the audience

title: Statisitical Analysis Report
section: Tools and Software for Statistical Reporting
text:
Tools and Software for Statistical Reporting

Tools overview:

R, Python, Quarto, Github, Excel, SPSS, Tableau

Choosing the right tool for your audience
Reproducibility

title: Statisitical Analysis Report
text:
Conclusion

Takeaway messages:

Clear communication is key
Tailor reports to the audience

Final thoughts and any questions?

title: Statistical Analysis Report
text:
This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com.
When you click the Knit button a document will be generated that includes both content as well as the output of any embedded R code chunks within the document. You can embed an R code chunk like this:

summary(cars)

     speed           dist       
 Min.   : 4.0   Min.   :  2.00  
 1st Qu.:12.0   1st Qu.: 26.00  
 Median :15.0   Median : 36.00  
 Mean   :15.4   Mean   : 42.98  
 3rd Qu.:19.0   3rd Qu.: 56.00  
 Max.   :25.0   Max.   :120.00

title: Statistical Analysis Report
text:
This is an R Markdown document. Markdown is a simple formatting syntax for authoring HTML, PDF, and MS Word documents. For more details on using R Markdown see http://rmarkdown.rstudio.com.
When you click the Knit button a document will be generated that includes both content as well as the output of any embedded R code chunks within the document. You can embed an R code chunk like this:

summary(cars)

     speed           dist       
 Min.   : 4.0   Min.   :  2.00  
 1st Qu.:12.0   1st Qu.: 26.00  
 Median :15.0   Median : 36.00  
 Mean   :15.4   Mean   : 42.98  
 3rd Qu.:19.0   3rd Qu.: 56.00  
 Max.   :25.0   Max.   :120.00

Including Plots

title: Schedule
text:
Harper Adams Data Science

This module is a part of the MSc in Data Science for Global Agriculture, Food, and Environment at Harper Adams University, led by Ed Harris.

title: Mini-project
text:
We have developed a new high-potential enhancer of biological nitrogen fixation (BNF) with nanotechnology which we believe can revolutionalise agriculture. It works by fostering long term relationships between beneficial soil microbes and plants. The technology works by affecting the gene expression of certain nitrogen-fixing bacteria such that they react to the presence of certain root exudates from a plant, and the presence of other bacteria that have been exposed to the same species in the past. This “wakes-up” dormant nitrogen fixing bacteria in a soil at an early crop growth stage, contributing to higher net BNF in the soil and better outcomes for the crop. Essentially, the nanotechnology builds a microbe-based memory system that allows for plants to be regrown in the same soil and with an enhanced chance of early BNF. We tested our nanotechnology against a no-treatment control and a regular BNF inoculant in randomized and replicated experiments with soya bean in 2016 and 2017. The experiments were randomized once, so the treatments occurred in the same exact plot in both years. The nanotechnology was only applied in 2016, so that we can examine if the effect lasts into 2017. Our hypothesis is that our treatment will outperform the regular BNF inoculant and the untreated control in yield in both years. We also hypothesise that the yield of the nanotechnology treatment on the same plot will improve in the second year. Finally, we believe that the regular BNF inoculation is still better than the control because these soils have poor nitrogen fixing bacteria due to excessive monocropping with cereals overtime.
Using the attached tidy data, please formulate appropriate null hypotheses to test our three alternate hypotheses. Conduct a statistical analysis based on the ANOVA technique and report whether our hypotheses are true or not. Conduct all the analysis in R and document the code comprehensively in a Quarto document.
Data

title: Mini-project
text:
We have developed a new high-potential enhancer of biological nitrogen fixation (BNF) with nanotechnology which we believe can revolutionalise agriculture. It works by fostering long term relationships between beneficial soil microbes and plants. The technology works by affecting the gene expression of certain nitrogen-fixing bacteria such that they react to the presence of certain root exudates from a plant, and the presence of other bacteria that have been exposed to the same species in the past. This “wakes-up” dormant nitrogen fixing bacteria in a soil at an early crop growth stage, contributing to higher net BNF in the soil and better outcomes for the crop. Essentially, the nanotechnology builds a microbe-based memory system that allows for plants to be regrown in the same soil and with an enhanced chance of early BNF. We tested our nanotechnology against a no-treatment control and a regular BNF inoculant in randomized and replicated experiments with soya bean in 2016 and 2017. The experiments were randomized once, so the treatments occurred in the same exact plot in both years. The nanotechnology was only applied in 2016, so that we can examine if the effect lasts into 2017. Our hypothesis is that our treatment will outperform the regular BNF inoculant and the untreated control in yield in both years. We also hypothesise that the yield of the nanotechnology treatment on the same plot will improve in the second year. Finally, we believe that the regular BNF inoculation is still better than the control because these soils have poor nitrogen fixing bacteria due to excessive monocropping with cereals overtime.
Using the attached tidy data, please formulate appropriate null hypotheses to test our three alternate hypotheses. Conduct a statistical analysis based on the ANOVA technique and report whether our hypotheses are true or not. Conduct all the analysis in R and document the code comprehensively in a Quarto document.
Data

title: Professional skills for data science
text:
Edit the following code so that the plot accurately reflects the axis labels and the subset functions returns an object with only the contents intended (as shown in the preceding comment to the function). Using indexing and regular expression tools in base R, extend the code to calculate the proportions of manual and automatic shift cars in the study

data(mpg)

# Scatter plot with base R
plot(mpg$disp1, mpg$hwy, col = as.factor(mpg$Year), 
     xlab = "Displacement", ylab = "Highway Miles per Gallon", pch = 19)
legend("topright", legend = unique(mpg$Year), col = unique(as.factor(mpg$Year)), pch = 19)

# Use base R to filter the data where cyl equals 8
subset(mpg, cy1 = '8')

Write pseudocode steps for calculating the volume of a cylinder (hint, if you do not know it by heart, you may need to research the equation for the volume of a cylinder!). For a cylinder of height = 3.2 cm and end radius of 5.5 cm, report the volume in cm to 2 decimal points of accuracy. Use at least 3 decimal points of accuracy for pi (hint, the quantity named pi is a standard variable in R!)
In your own words, what value is required for the d argument in the pwr.t.test() function in the {pwr} package? Show the code involved including any appropriate comment code required to answer this question. (hint: you will probably need to install the package, load it, and use help() on the function name)
Using the code chunk below, please answer the following questions:


What is the role of the set.seeed() function in the context of this code?
Why does calculating the mean of the copied original matrix return a numeric value while the mean of the same matrix when missing values are filled from the list returns NA?
Please fix the code sp that mean_of_original_copy and mean_matrix are equal

# Step 1: Create a 3x3 matrix with random numbers, and introduce NAs
set.seed(123) 
matrix_with_na <- matrix(sample(c(NA, 1:9), 9, replace = TRUE), nrow = 3)
copy_of_original<-matrix_with_na
matrix_with_na[1,2] <- NA  # Introduce 3 specific NAs
matrix_with_na[2,3] <- NA
matrix_with_na[3,1] <- NA


print("Original Matrix with NAs:")
print(matrix_with_na)

# Step 2: Create a list with the same structure but no NAs
list_with_values <- as.list(as.character(matrix(1:9, nrow = 3)))
print(list_with_values)

# Step 3: Use a for-loop to find the corresponding missing number from the list and fill the matrix
for (i in 1:3) {
  for (j in 1:3) {
    if (is.na(matrix_with_na[i,j])) {
      matrix_with_na[i,j] <- list_with_values[[(i-1)*3 + j]]  # Replace with corresponding value from list
    }
  }
}

print(matrix_with_na)

# Step 4: Try calculating the mean of the matrices
mean_matrix <- mean(matrix_with_na)
mean_of_original_copy <- mean(copy_of_original)
print(mean_of_original_copy)
print(mean_matrix)

Explain why this function is not working and return the working equivalent. Interpret what the estimate means and rank the species

# Load necessary package
install.packages('emmeans')
library(emmeans)

run_anova_posthoc <- function() {
  # Perform ANOVA on the iris dataset
  anova_result <- aov(Sepal.Length ~ Species, data = iris)
  
  # Perform post-hoc test using emmeans
  posthoc_result <- emmeans(anova_result, pairwise ~ Species)
  
  comparisons <- as.data.frame(posthoc_result$contrasts)
  
  print(comparisons)
  comparisons_df <- data.frame(Species = comparisons$species,
                               estimate = comparisons$estimate,
                               p.value = comparisons$p.value)
  
  return(comparisons_df)
}


run_anova_posthoc()

Using the iris dataset in R, conduct an anova of sepal length ‘by hand’ and report the F statistic. Feel free to use other packages for data wrangling/grouping only, but for each function used, appropriately comment on what it does and which package it comes from. Show your R code.
Write your own question similar in spirit, difficulty and scope to questions 3-6 above. Provide a full question including any code prompts. Also supply a full answer including any commented code required.
Write your own question similar in spirit, difficulty and scope to questions 3-6 above. Provide a full question including any code prompts. Also supply a full answer including any commented code required.

Why does calculating the mean of the copied original matrix return a numeric value while the mean of the same matrix when missing values are filled from the list returns NA?

# Step 1: Create a 3x3 matrix with random numbers, and introduce NAs
set.seed(123) 
matrix_with_na <- matrix(sample(c(NA, 1:9), 9, replace = TRUE), nrow = 3)
copy_of_original<-matrix_with_na
matrix_with_na[1,2] <- NA  # Introduce 3 specific NAs
matrix_with_na[2,3] <- NA
matrix_with_na[3,1] <- NA


print("Original Matrix with NAs:")

# Step 2: Create a list with the same structure but no NAs
list_with_values <- as.list(as.character(matrix(1:9, nrow = 3)))
print(list_with_values)

# Step 3: Use a for-loop to find the corresponding missing number from the list and fill the matrix
for (i in 1:3) {
  for (j in 1:3) {
    if (is.na(matrix_with_na[i,j])) {
      matrix_with_na[i,j] <- list_with_values[[(i-1)*3 + j]]  # Replace with corresponding value from list
    }
  }
}

print(matrix_with_na)

# Step 4: Try calculating the mean of the matrices
mean_matrix <- mean(matrix_with_na)
mean_of_original_copy <- mean(copy_of_original)
print(mean_of_original_copy)

Explain why this function is not working and return the working equivalent. Interpret what the estimate means and rank the species

# Load necessary package
install.packages('emmeans')
library(emmeans)

run_anova_posthoc <- function() {
  # Perform ANOVA on the iris dataset
  anova_result <- aov(Sepal.Length ~ Species, data = iris)
  
  # Perform post-hoc test using emmeans
  posthoc_result <- emmeans(anova_result, pairwise ~ Species)
  
  comparisons <- as.data.frame(posthoc_result$contrasts)
  
  print(comparisons)
  comparisons_df <- data.frame(Species = comparisons$species,
                               estimate = comparisons$estimate,
                               p.value = comparisons$p.value)
  
  return(comparisons_df)
}


run_anova_posthoc()
